description: Unknown, but probably originally Mog +‎ -y, a Scots or Northern English variant of maggie (“girl”), from Maggie, a diminutive of Margaret and Margery. First attested in reference to mongrel cats in Cockney.

entries.meaning: (Scotland and Northern England regional, obsolete) Synonym of girl: a female child or young woman.
examples: ...expect not so fair an enemy as Cromwel, nor such fair quarter as now is given thee: Jockey, Jemmy, and Moggy thy she-souldier, must than all to the sword...

entries.meaning: (Midlands and Northern England regional, derogatory, rare) Synonym of slattern: an unkempt or badly-dressed woman.
examples: Moggy, a slattern, dressed out untidily: 'She did look a moggy.'

entries.meaning: (Midlands and Northern England regional, rare) Synonym of scarecrow.
(UK) A domestic cat, especially (depreciative or derogatory) a non-pedigree or unremarkable cat.
(Yorkshire) A kind of cake made with ginger, treacle, etc.
